James fascination owes as much to the certainties of her class  as to her looks. An attractive young man accompanies her up the stairs. Jeremy makes a sound.  Susan Glances up.

Then the drinks tray is suddenly i their midst and they all reach out thankfully, with mock  groans of relief and surprise. An hour later, Guests are leaving.  James has got Susan  alone.  They descend the stairs.  CLOSE ON Susan, a  disparate kind of seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, in many ways I'm right  behind the women's movement.  But  sometimes I wish they'd get on  with it instead of moaning on.   The office was split right down  the middle.  I mean, as a woman I  understood what they were saying,  that current affairs was all about  what men did, but as a human being  and a television researcher, as a  professional , I could just sense  they'd got it all wrong.  I could  see there were two paths I could  go down, power or not-power.  Down  the not-power path was lot of  sisterly feeling, masochism and  frustration.  Down the other path,  I could keep on working.  So of  course I voted with the men and  the other women all resigned.  I  think they're mad, don't you?

dialogues.text: I was only ten years old at the  time, but it was the first  international crises I can remember. And now, suddenly, with  this Falklands business on us,  it's quite clear we do need to  take another look at 1956.  The  way I see the book is that it would  get away completely--

Then there's the essential--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

A  good ally is one who doesn't back  you up in your mistakes, who tells  you when to pull back.  And the  Americans were good allies.  Simple  as that.

dialogues.text: James is immensely pleased with his own performance durin this speech.  Gold, however, is more interested in someth he has seen in a shop window.  As soon as James finishes, Gold mumbles an apology and plunges into the shop.  James follows him in.

dialogues.text: Have you got to do straight off?

dialogues.text: No, not yet.

dialogues.text: Good...stay here a bit.

dialogues.text: James sits.  His mother falls into a deep sleep.

dialogues.text: She's asleep.

As they talk they make a complicated route through the Arts Centre, always on the verge of getting lost.

dialogues.text: A little later.  A Private View.  A discreetly murmuring, wine, canapГ©s. The paintings - painfully pretentious - represent various forms of aesthetic self-consciousness. James and Susan look at the pictures, but make no referen to them.  They spend a little time in front of each one  before moving to the next.  James speech is broken by  moments of contemplation.  As they move on again, he pick up his thread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone describes the same process.   At first it is exciting.  You're  at the centre of the world.  As  soon as anything happens, you're  the first to know about it.  And  there are deadlines a dozen times  a day, even more, and that's  intimidating and exciting.  Then  you get the hang of it and the  excitement wears off.  Your a clerk  in a rather dowdy Office.  There's  none of the glamour of television,  or the penetration of serious  journalism.  You're a processor of  semi-official news.  Some people  leave at this stage.  Then, if you  hang on, and especially if you're  promoted, you discover a new kind  of pleasure.  You're pleased by  the ease with which you can write  summaries and bulletins from news  agency printouts, by the way you  ca judge length.  Ending a broadcast  on the dot, having everything run  smoothly, selecting a running order  that makes sense, knowing  instinctively what you can and  cannot do.  Professionalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're at this third stage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's a fourth.  Numbness.   You do everything right, but you  feel nothing either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're exaggerating.  And  if you aren't, you should jolly  well change your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  You're much too old to making  a drama out of alienation, or  whatever you call it.  You've got  to take responsibility for your  own happiness.  That's what I think  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan has moved on a couple of steps and is bending forwa to look at a picture.  James smiles at her wonderingly, a little deflated, but impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy is sprawled in a chair with a drink.  James is  standing.  Muted piano music from the stereo.  EDWARD has just entered.  The other two have been waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Poet Laureate himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward approaches.  He is a contemporary of the other two but looks much younger and less worldly in manner.  He is slightly nervous.  He works on a literary magazine and he is a poet whose work is just beginning to be recognised. The three are old friends.  Jeremy and James keep up thei friendship with Edward because they recognise his talent, and this makes them feel more authentic.  Edward keeps up with them because he is lonely and his own life is rather dull.  However, he does distrust them a little.  And they keep his talent in place by teasing him. As Edward enters the other two applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward makes a nervous mock bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Have you two been  smoking that illegal stuff again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James pours wine into Edward's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were admiring your poem in the  TLS, Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terribly good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you've actually read  it, Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James picks up the TLS and waves it at Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Committed to memory.  Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BlasГ© and epicene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just chortling over that.   BlasГ© and epicene.  It perfectly  describes the new Foreign Secretary.   So--I hope you don't mind, Edward,  I pinched it for my piece today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attributed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, is there a new Foreign  Secretary?  Who was the old one  anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It needn't concern you, Edward.   James has got some news.  He needs  a poet's advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy pats a seat.  Edward sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  I don't want any Jones  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No jokes.  James is in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.  Who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glamorous young lady way above  his station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name so Susie Barrington.  Daughter  of the eminent historian, Anne  Barrington, step-daughter of the  scandalous Matthew Byrd the  acclaimed sack-artist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay over Jeremy's account on next scene and FADE DOWN  SLOWLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sumptuously cluttered place.  A chesterfield.  Deep  armchairs, silk cushions, many prints, coffee table, book Clearly an inherited place. Susan is pouring coffee.  James sits across from her, jac off, sunk in cushions. JEREMY'S VOICE OVER RECEDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mummy and I, we were more like  lovers, really, or sisters.  Then  a couple of years after Daddy died,  and not long after I left Oxford,  she started seeing various men and  I was furious.  I really was upset.   I stopped going home.  I never  phoned.  I went round telling  everyone how awful her books were.   And she hardly seemed to notice,  and that made me angrier.  Then I  got a job I was interested in, and  I started to see lots of men, and  I suppose I grew up a little and  began to understand.  So I wrote  her a long letter, almost seven  pages, saying how sorry I was, and  how I was worried that we were  drifting apart.  And do you know,  she wrote me a poem, a really  beautiful poem about mothers and  daughters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me weepy just to remember  it.  So we were fine again, and  then she got married to Matthew  who's a womaniser and a bit of a  yob, but quite nice really, makes  TV commercials.  What about yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be rather nice, in a  way.  I mean, you don't have any--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bell RINGS loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  They're early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called you a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a gesture of  helplessness) Well, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minute later, James and Susan stand at the front door. Portico and steps down to the street.  Taxi waits.  They  kiss, Susan draws back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, if you like.  Call me at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James descends the stairs.  Susan closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cocktail bar, a self-conscious imitation of the America model.  James and Jeremy sit on high stools at the bar.   Tall colourful drinks are being set down in front of them On a TV there are scenes of the departing Royal Navy flee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Fleet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Fleet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Argies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Argies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy reaches into his inside pocket and pulls out an  envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, top secret file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for it) Come on.  Hand over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy outs the envelope out of James's reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Tell me what you think of  this first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You approve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get way.  You'll see when I'm ready.   First I want you to reflect on my  noble behaviour, on how your  interests are closest to my heart,  how I lay awake at night worrying--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy, just let me see what you've  got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so hard.  All right then.   I was chatting to some people from  the diary page, and the name of  Barrington came up.  I expressed  an interest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...an innocent interest, and found  out that last year Vogue ran a  series called 'Mothers and  Daughters' Number seven, Anne and  Susan Barrington.  Being a decent  loving friend I went to the files  and made a copy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, ah.  There's more.  The piece  celebrates the undying affection  between eminent left-wing historian  and he dazzling daughter.  Then  the news editor, who happened to  be in the room, said that years  ago, when he worked on The Guardian,  Anne Barrington had written a very  good piece on...guess...Suez.  It  was 1966, the tenth anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy hands over the envelope which James now opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's never written a book in it,  but she clearly knew a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obvious what you have to do.   Your way into the daughter's pants  is through the mother, up the Suez  canal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very nice, apparently.  Lives  in Norfolk.  And very left-wing.   You'll have to watch yourself there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to this, the daughter  goes up to stay quiet often.  You'll  need to get yourself invited for  the right weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've really got it all worked  out, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to thank me, if you don't  want to.  Just pay for these drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be eleven pounds, sir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James walks along a busy corridor in a polytechnic.  In a recess to one side is a games room.  Along the walls are  Space Invader machines by the dozen.  Students stand at  the machines intently, their faces illuminated by the glo We SEE some expertly handled Space Invader action.  James approaches one of the players and asks directions.  Witho looking up the student points down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James stands outside the doors or a lecture hall.  Inside a lecture is in progress.  We catch a few words. James pushes the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LECTURER glances back and acknowledges his presence. James stands at the back of the hall for the end of the  lecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vacuum had been created.  If the  United States did not fill it, it  was assumed the Russians would. (A beat) Next week I shall be considering  the extent to which the behaviour  of nation states or governments  may be judged by the moral criteria  we normally apply to individuals.   Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students stand and begin to move out.  James and the  Lecturer move towards each other and shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and the Lecturer sit separated by a low table.  A  tape-recorder is on the Lecturer's side of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what you need to understand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sorry, could you lean forward  a bit when you speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Is this all right?  Um...you  see, through the early autumn of  1956 the Egyptians were running  the canal, their canal, that is,  quite efficiently.  Traffic was  passing through unimpeded, for  Nasser didn't want to provide the  West with any reason for invading  his country.  Is that loud enough,  by the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  So by the time the British  and French launched their invasion  at the beginning of November the  main economic reasons for doing so  had largely evaporated.  What  remained, especially for the  British, were the more marginal  and emotional arguments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lecturer's voice continues on the tape.  James pours drink and he listens and walks towards his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from tape) Using the language of private  behaviour you could say that this  was an affair of the heart - the  idea was to teach Nasser a lesson,  to appear capable of acting  independently, and to maintain  face in the world, particularly  the Arab world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James switches the tape recorder off.  He picks up the  Vogue 'Mothers and Daughters' article and pins it to the  map of Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poetry reading, given by Edward Long, has just come to  and end.  There are about fifty present, and empty chairs behind.  Jeremy and James are in the audience. Edward is reading the last stanza of a poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "And so the ferry moves across the  bay, Top heavy as a wedge of wedding  cake, Leaving us to return to our  hotels, Gulls in nautical trim cry  their farewells, Then drop with  avaricious eyes to tale, Souvenirs  from the debris of the day."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is earnest applause which peters out.  Now, a tense silence. Edward stares impassively at the audience until he catche the movement of a half-raised arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The questioner is a middle-class middle-aged woman, rathe twittery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, well I thought I'd start  the thing off by asking, you know,  and you'll probably think it's a  stupid question that you get all  the time, but could you tell us a  little of how you actually get  ideas, I mean, your poems are quiet  extraordinary and beautiful and I  wondered how they, well, you know,  came about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, Jeremy has caught James's eye and they have  started to giggle silently.  This continues through the  scene.  They hunch up and turn away from each other, shak quietly, half recover, become aware of each other, or of  the absurdity of the questions, or of Edward's attempts t deal with them, and they fold up once more.  From Edward' POV we SEE their heads duck down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't a stupid question, but it  is a difficult one to answer.  I  get ideas in much the same way as  anyone does.  Perhaps the difference  is that I take them more seriously.   I write them down - odd scraps of  things.  Then I seem to know when  I'm ready to start work on a poem.   It takes shape to start work on a  poem.  It takes shape as I write  it, very slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Edward answers, the woman nods vigorously. James and Jeremy recover in the brief pause between  questions.  They lift tear-stained faces, then crack up a the next question. A young man, anorak, flat auto-didact's 'does the team  think' voice.  A piece of paper in hand, he stands,  trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one of the most praised  poets of your generation of younger  poets, and the Sunday Times has  called you a cross between Dante  and Philip Larkin.  What is your  reaction to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's silly really. (catching sight of  Jeremy and James) It's journalism, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A serious-looking student has his hand raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  What is the poet's role in  society today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON James, drawing breath.  A sudden sharp yelp from Jeremy fighting for air.  All heads turn.  The two are  almost off their seats onto the floor.  We move CLOSE ON  them and hear their moans or 'No', 'No' and 'Stop', 'stop and 'Sorry!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newsroom.  The teleprinters.  The sheets arriving on  the copytaster's desk.  On the TV monitor there are pictu of the Fleet.  On the P.A. a voice announces 'Edward Du  Cann on Four'. We find PHILIP standing by the bulletin desk, He is a  graduate trainee, 23 years old.  Earnest in manner, sligh ingratiating. Immensely pleased with what he has just read, he moves  towards the summaries desk with a piece of paper in each  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, look at this.  At last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is standing by a secretary dictating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...and with talks at the United  Nations still making little  progress, tension and anxiety  settled on MPs of all parties in  Westminster.  Speaking on the Jimmy  Young Show earlier today, Mrs  Thatcher said the prospects of a  peaceful solution did not look  encouraging.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James glances over the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen news items.  I got exactly  the same running order as the  bulletin desk.  They're all old  pros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philip moves on to show someone else nearby.  We hear him explain his triumph again. James makes a gesture and expression of contempt for the  benefit of the secretaries. A group of journalists passes through.  James catches one of them by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use the phone in your office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small bare office.  A few minutes later, James is speak on the phone to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) You're being very elusive...tell  them you're ill...or leave early  then...do it properly, tell them a  lie...Okay, come when you can.   You've got the address...yes, it  will be nice.  'Bye..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan sits cross-legged in the centre of James's bed.   James lies along one edge, head propped on elbows.  They' been drinking coffee.  We have the sense of a long evenin of talk, but not much else so far.  A pause before Susan  speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be up early. (She stands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening  herself at the  mirror. James  standing close) Two or three years ago I would  have stayed.  And fucked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late.  Just my luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands behind her and kisses her neck.  She turns and  they kiss.  Susan pulls away.  She taps James's nose with her forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm more wary.  I must be  getting old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for her coat.  James helps her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust anyone.  That's what  comes of working in television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In radio we're different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet.  Thanks for the drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might see you in Norfolk over  the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You just might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door on her smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day later.  A glass-fronted Squash Court.  James and  Jeremy are into a game.  Both are inept and very unfit.   We COME IN on a rally.  Jeremy misses an easy ball and  let's his racket drop.  James sits down with his back to  the wall.  Jeremy gets his cigarettes from the corner of  the court.  They inhale smoke as if it were fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been playing ten minutes for  Christ sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.  Some keen SQUASH PLAYERS appear at the door,  peer in and go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everyone's desperate for a  new Falkland's angle.  Purdy's  come up with a real dog.  Worker's  rights in Argentina.  So I've been  running round getting people to do  things.  But no one's keen.  Workers  rights.  When did anyone on that  paper give a damn about workers  rights?  I said to Purdy, "Look,  tits, bingo, jingo, horoscope,  sport, celebs, gossip and the  occasional firm stand on--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The torture of small children--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the torture of very small  children, but don't start telling  them about their rights--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold those rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tame those rights...you know, we're  even freighting in a couple of  exiled Argie trade unionists from  Paris for a TV tie in.  One of  them had his balls tap-danced on  by the secret police.  The other  one had to be hosed off the wall  of his cell after the police-- yes  my good man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A muscular COACH in a tracksuit, is rapping on the glass  door.  And opening it.  He wears a towel around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  This is a private  conversation.  You'll have to wait  outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't smoke in here.  This is  a squash court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we booked it for a smoke,  didn't we James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're not quiet finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few players have gathered to watch outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court is ours for another half  hour.  Please run along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach advances into the court, picks up their rackets and stands over them.  He pushes a racket under Jermey's  chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, we might be  more comfortable at the bar.  I've  got some news on Suez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (racket still under  his chin) A serious drunk might be of use, I  suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James adjusts his tie in the mirror.  The PHONE RINGS, La over James's voice into SCENES 38 and 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohm hello, Dad, I've been meaning  to phone you.  How is she?...Oh...in  the night?...Oh God.  What does  the doctor say?...Look, I will, I  will.  I promise.  But it's  impossible at the moment, now with  the crisis on.  I'm working night  and day...Look, tell her I'll come  as soon as I can.  I promise...Look,  Dad, I've got to dash.  Give her  my love.  Yes...bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James walks down a Brixton street, down a narrow road to set of lock-up garages.  A group of black kids are playin football here.  James steps round puddles, careful not to muddy his shoes.  He scowls at the kids and unlocks his  garage. James backs his car out of the garage.  An early sixties  Jaguar saloon.  He gets to close to the garage door.  The game of football rages around his car, as if it was not  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes later.  A car wash.  From the driver's POV we SEE the revolving brushes advance and engulf the car. The phone conversation ends.  James reaches down and push a tape into the car tape deck.  We will HEAR the recordin all through James's journey to SCENE 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from tape) You see, if we talk of a nation,  like an individual, we can also  speak of it acting deceitfully.   Britain and France had entered  into a secret agreement with the  Arabs' deadly enemy, the Israelis.   The agreement was signed or  initialled by the Foreign Secretary,  Selwyn Lloyd on about October 23,  at Sevres.  The Israelis were to  attack Egypt on an agreed date.   British planes based in Cyprus  were to precision bomb Egyptian  airfields to protect Israeli cities  from retaliation.  After putting  out an ultimatum to both side to  withdraw to ten miles from the  Canal, which of course the Egyptians  would have to ignore since the  Canal is 100 miles inside their  territory, the British and the  French would invade on the pretext  of 'separating the combatants'.   That became something of a catch  phrase - 'Separating the  combatants'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James's car makes its way through the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later.  The M11. James's car speeds away from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour and a half later.  James drives along a country  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small BOY, TOM, peers over a wall at James's car as it  sweeps into the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes later.  The Barrington house.  The library. James waits alone.  The house stands in its own grounds - an old rectory, spacious, but not over-grand.  Much charm 19th and 20th Century oil paintings, a serious reader's  library.  Pleasant disorder, but no squalor.  There is on housekeeper. Somewhere in the house a PHONE RINGS.  There are footstep James crosses to a window which faces out over the garden which is large and well-kept.At some distance away a  gardener is raking leaves.  Another man comes and talks t him and then disappears from sight.  This is MATHEW, Anne Barrington's husband. The door opens slowly.  TOM, the ten year old son of  Matthew, stares at James. After a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said awfully sorry, make  yourself comfortable, she won't be  long. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not sit down and wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not my mother, anyway.  My  mother's in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you come to talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  History.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this Tom leaves the door and advances into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suez.  1956.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to hear my list of  English Kings and Queens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes from Henry VIII. (In rapid monotone) Henry VIII, Edward IV, Mary,  Elizabeth I, James I, Charles I,  Charles II, James II, William and  Mary, Ann, George I, II, III and  IV, Victoria, Edward VII, George  V, Edward VIII, George IV, Elizabeth  II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Cromwells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Barrington comes in.  Aged about fifty-five, very  attractive still, and fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Penfield.  I am sorry to have  kept you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of you to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, Daddy would like to see you  in the garden.  And will you ask  Betty to bring us some coffee.   And remember to say 'please'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom leaves.  They watch as he closes the door with  exaggerated care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a little unhappy.  I hope he  wasn't a nuisance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was delightful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes later.  Anne sits behind her desk, James sits across from her.  The HOUSEKEEPER sets down a tray and  leaves. Anne appraises James and deals with the coffee, and for  the first time in the film we take a long, hard look at  him too.  The light flatters.  The notebook at his side,  his patience and deference, the well-cut suit...he is at  least credible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first husband worked for the  BBC.  I doubt if anyone there  remembers him now, just another  long dead diligent administrator.   He would have been useful in the  fight to preserve the BBC's  independence during the Suez crisis -  one of the few things he was  passionate about.  I became involved  too.  I started work on a book  that would have been published on  the tenth anniversary of Suez.   Then he died, and I loots the will  to write it.  By the time I was  over his death, other books had  been published, and it wasn't worth  going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't much more than a pot  boiler.Suez was very important for  our generation.  I didn't want it  to be forgotten.  And that's why  I'd like to be able to help you.   But really Mr. Penfield, I looked  through my notes before you came,  they're all very much out of date,  there's been so much published  since.  I don't think I'm your  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, uncertain) Well, I am a great admirer of your  work.  I read your books on Chartism  when I was still at school.  I'm a  journalist, not a historian.  There  are questions of method, and  approach.  I wondered--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  Are you a socialist, Mr.  Penfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Suez was a minefield for  both parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Garden, same time.  Tom wanders aimlessly near the  house.  He comes to one of the library windows and peers  in. Unobserved, he watches Ann and James.  Ann is speaking.   James interrupts, Anne nods.  James writes something down in his notebook. Tom hears his father in the distance calling his name.  H leaves the window and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunchtime.  A table spread with white tablecloth, salads  and wine.  Set for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband apologises for not  joining us.  It's not too cold for  you, Mr. Penfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you are a friend of my  daughter's, I think I'm entitled  to call you James, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please do.  I was beginning to  wonder who this Mr. Penfield was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd like you to call me Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To James.  I remember what it was  I was going to say.  We were talking  about forgetfulness.  The Czech  writer Kundera has one of his  characters say that the struggle  of man against tyranny is the  struggle of memory against  forgetting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History books are first onto the  bonfires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we leave the remembering to  historians then the struggle is  already lost.  Everyone must have  a memory, everyone needs to be a  historian.  In this country, for  example, we're in danger of losing  hard-won freedoms by dozing off in  a perpetual present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is uneasy, a little out of his depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am lecturing you.  Have  some pГўtГ©.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Pause.  Ann has already emptied her glass.  James has  hardly touched his.  Ann refills her own.  Then James,  lightly, wanting to be back on familiar ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I can go ahead and be a historian  without feeling like a poseur.I  shall be fulfilling a citizen's  duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you like.  But don't be too  modest, James.  The citizen's duty  is to remember, not necessarily to  write books.  You are highly  qualified.  You're a responsible  journalist doing what sounds to me  like a very demanding job.  Every  day you take decisions that depend  on your sense of history.  A genuine  tyranny would have to get rid of  people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kind to be so encouraging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll do very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and briefly touches James's hand.  James looks up impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and James are returning from an after-lunch walk.  W have a glimpse of the landscape we will see more of on  James's return. As they walk they arrive through a back gate into the  Barrington garden.  A jet fighter races through the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've met some of her colleagues,  I'm afraid they struck me as rather  empty people.  Very ambitious, and  charming too.  But not serious.   No politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do worry about Susan.  Have you  known her long?  She hasn't  mentioned you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, we've only just met.   But we're quiet good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pity she couldn't make it  up here today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be here next weekend.  Why  don't you come too, James?  I'll                       * show you the marshes properly.  If  you're lucky you might even see  the first of the geese arriving  from Siberia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd hate to be a nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly.  I'll look out  some more Suez material for you.   You'll be very welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come round the front of the house to James's car.  H opens the door and shakes Ann's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see you next week, and if--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew's car comes sweeping up the drive.  Tom is in the front seat.  Matthew stops his car so that his front door is by James. MATTHEW is fifty.  A director of commercials for cinema  and television.  Breezy, chunky-faced, keen to be taken  seriously.  Essentially good-humoured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't drive so fast,  Mat, dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get a bike.  I promise.  Hi!   Just off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew and James shake hands over the car doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew my husband.  James.  James  is coming to stay next weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.  Well, I'll see you  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides away with Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Tom.  Let's see if we can  get this thing working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James pulls away.  Ann stands watching him till he is out of sight, and a little longer after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes later.  James drives along the A149 near Clay He has the window wide open, the radio on.  The great  expanse of salt marsh is to his right.  The huge sky.  Th mood is triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later.  A lonely road in central Norfolk.   James brings the car to a sudden halt.  He switches off  the engine.  In the silence we are able to hear the car  cassette player.  As it plays, James walks round the car  till he finds his flat tyre.  He rummages with growing il temper in the boot.  Two cases of empty wine bottles, a  mildewed towel and swimming trunks, but no jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from tape) There was a real desire on the  British part to appear virtuous  while behaving aggressively, and  the pursuit of virtue led to many  lies being told, most notable the  Prime Minister's in the House of  Commons on December 20 when he  said that there was 'no  foreknowledge that Israel would  attack Egypt'.  Perhaps we should  reverse the question and ask  ourselves to what extent individuals  behave like governments, who are  bound to act in the national  interest which in turn is rarely  separable from the government's  interest, or that of the class it  represents...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious, he goes to the front of the car and snaps off th tape machine, and stands jiggling his keys in the vast  silence. A minute later.  James sets off.  The immensity of the  landscape, the incongruousness of his clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road passes through a wood.  When BETTY speaks, it  surprises both James and us. She stands at the head of a little grass track that leads into a wood.  She carries a plastic carrier bag.  She is  almost childlike in her friendliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the man from the BBC?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  I didn't mean to frighten  you.  I thought you must be from  the BBC. (she advances) We've been waiting, see.  And you  don't exactly look like a farmer.   I'm Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Penfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and meet the others.  They've  been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James follows Betty through the woods.  A rumbling and  whining noise increases in violence and becomes deafening once they leave the wood and cross open ground towards a  Military Air Base.  The Peace Camp is near the perimeter  fence.  A ramshackle collection of tents, caravans, a tep and a rough wooden shelter which is the communal area.  A fire burns here.  Various peace signs, Women's Movement  sign and slogan.  ('Fight War, Not Wars', etc.) Three women are sitting around the fire.  A little furthe off a MAN is chopping wood.  One of the women, CARMEN, is over sixty.  The other two are in their thirties.  The  man, PETE, is a vintage hippy.  A good mix of regional  accents among the campers.  Betty leads James to the fire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a man from the BBC, but  he's not the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  We'll just have to  make do.  Would you like a cup of  tea?  Jill, give the young man  your cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Dodging smoke from  the fire) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit on that log, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful though, it wobbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, listen, I... I've got a  puncture.  I wondered if I might  borrow a jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to be a nuisance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete ambles over.  Inscrutable behind much hair.  He  registers no awareness of James.  He smokes a roll-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, do we have a jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete inhales, considers and nods almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you look it out for our  friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete nods again and returns to chopping wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the tea all right?  I didn't  ask you if you wanted sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now first of all, tell us your  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penfield.  James Penfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Jill, Carol, Betty, Mandy,  Louise, Pete over there, and I'm  Carmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women smile and murmur hello as they are introduced. Their friendliness progressively disorientates James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another fifteen of us out  at a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like us to show you round  the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him drink his tea, poor man.   I don't know what's happened to  this other fellow.  He said he'd  be here at three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do at the BBC, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work in radio news, in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of 'Oh well then ... 'and 'Great!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not an interviewer or a  correspondent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't matter.  As long as  we can get our message through to  someone there.  Jill, where are  those handouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're back here somewhere.   They're a bit crumpled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete hands a jack to James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now James has his jack he begins to back away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give them here.  This tells you  how the Women's Peace Camp came to  be set up.  All local women at  first, then we had support from  women and men all over the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The response has been just amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this sheet tells you all about  the base, the number of missiles  they're going to have, what they  think they're for and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had the local radio down  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what we need is national  coverage.  It's difficult with  this Falklands madness going on.   Do you think you might be able to  do something when you get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll suggest it.  Remember though,  we're news, not features.  It might  help if you could get yourselves  attacked by the police.  Anyway,  I'll be back with this soon.   Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close up, eyes  wide) Ordinary people everywhere are  saying 'No, we don't want these  terrible weapons!'  That's news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James drives down the road towards the airbase.  He stops his car well short of the camp.  He takes the jack from  the car and walks towards the camp.  There are more peopl now moving in and out of the light of the fire.  The soun of voices, laughter, mostly female.  A meal is being cook James sets down the jack where it can be found.  He has  been observed throughout by Pete, from the shadows.  He  speaks as James is turning back towards his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, yes, I put the jack by the ...  hut there.  Thanks for your help  ... I... I have to be getting back  ... so ... see you.  And thanks  ... and ... all the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete watches James walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London.  A day later.  The television company where Susan works.  James is late.  The lift is out of order.  He run up several flights of stairs with diminishing energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathless, James bursts into the screening room.  Susan  is seated.  Jeremy stands near her, leaning against a des smoking.  By contrast, they are calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortunate that I was here to keep  Susan entertained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  Got held up.  What are you  doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivering gossip and goodwill.   It seems we'll both be doing  Brighton. (He starts to put  on his coat) Perhaps you should come too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan) Will it be fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might be able to dig out a couple  of Suez survivors for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I will, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Kissing on the  cheek first Susan,  then James) I'm off.  Let's meet.  You promised  to tell me about Norfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ring you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief pause and a slight awkwardness after Jeremy leave

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) I think we're ready now, thank  you.  And how was Norfolk?  Did  you get on with my mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she liked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  We talked about history, and  Siberian Geese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go down. We SEE a series of FILM CLIPS about Suez: crowd scenes in Cairo; footage of the Fleet on its way from Malta; the  actual invasion; parachutes; Eden at Downing Street; Lloy at the airport; the protest meeting at Trafalgar Square;  fighting in Suez streets. James sneaks occasional looks at Susan throughout.  We SE her in profile, lit by the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As the first  pictures come up) It's not in chronological order.   There's an hour of stuff, of which  the director has to choose four  minutes.  What'll happen is that  I'll choose it for him ... Does he  look like a man on speed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our two minute sequence is presented to represent an hour of film.  When at last it is over and the lights come up, there is a moment of stupefaction.  Susan yawns and prepa to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she's invited you up  for her sake or for mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing Susan's  fingers) I haven't really thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, mischievous) Well, you should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James kisses Susan.  She complies rather than responds. Susan disengages herself gently and gathers her things.   She stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, must get on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day or two later.  People are drifting out to go down  the corridor to the morning news conference.  James is on of the last to leave.  On his way out he meets Charles,  the newsreader from Scene two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles!  I didn't know you were  back.  Have a good holiday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too bad, thanks.  How have you  been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working hard on that book I was  telling you about.  Coming to the  meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep me company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James steers Charles out of the newsroom and along the  corridor.  Only slowly does it become apparent that Charl is in a state of distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine.  Well, actually we've  broken up.  It's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's terrible, Charles.   What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the edge of  tears) Look, I'd rather you didn't ask me  questions.  I can't talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the News Conference Room, but Charles  walks on down the corridor to nurse his grief out of sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The News Conference Room.  Ten minutes later.  The same  Editor.  The same matter-of-factness and slight boredom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....as it happens they got all  their facts wrong anyway.  I checked  up.  We reported the big peace  march on Hyde Park last October,  and a march on NATO headquarters  in the spring, and the death of  whatsisname last month, the old  CND man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks round.  It is not clear that anyone is listening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What really gets to them, though  they'll never admit it, these types,  is that we give both sides, theirs  and the government's.   Multilateralists and unilateralists.   Hawks and doves.  As far as they're  concerned, there's only one side  to the question.  Nuclear weapons  are bad.  Full stop.  End of  discussion.  Anyone who says there's  more to it than that is... what  was it... (He picks up a  newspaper cutting) 'Under cover of an authoritative  news service, propagating a military  definition of reality.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, relaxes into professional indifference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still.  With the party conferences  coming up in the autumn there's  bound to be some action on that  front and we'd be doing something  anyway.  It won't all be Falklands  business.  James, is there something  in there for us, if we could tie  it in with something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's all a bit cranky and  small scale.  Vegetarians, hippies,  disturbed housewives.  Local radio  story, I'd say, if that.  They're  mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well.  Just an idea.  Now.  Can  we talk about this radio-car cock- up yesterday.  Chris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours later.  The studio.  James and Charles sit at  the table, as in Scene Three.  Charles reads.  He is  obviously distressed but his voice remains under control. James watches anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an emotional occasion.   Hundreds of small craft led by six  fire tugs making fountains of water  formed an escort flotilla, and  four Wasp helicopters flew past in  salute.  In the City the Financial  Times Ordinary Shares Index was  down ten points an hour ago at  529.8. BBC Radio News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Control Room, the minute hand of the clock reaches five past the hour; the sweep hand reaches the twelve on  Charles's last word.  The Controller pushes a button.   Charles slumps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God that was close!  Well done,  Charles.  I knew you wouldn't let  me down.  But God!  We almost didn't  make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is standing, gathering papers.  He bustles out,  indifferent.  We CLOSE IN on Charles.  Unseen by anyone,  he is just beginning to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is typing rapidly.  There is a growing pile of  typewritten sheets to one side.  We go over his shoulder  and look closely at the map, Egypt, the desert . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later.  James has just arrived and switched hi engine off.  But for the wind and birdsong, silence.  The is no reply when he tries the front door.  A note pinned  to the door reads: 'Gone for a walk.  Follow footpath.   Susan.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James walks along the dyke, across the marshes.  Below  him, on the sand, in the distance, are two figures.  Jame stops to watch them.  Matthew and Susan are deep in  conversation В— evidently a serious matter.  They seem to be making an agreement.  Matthew puts his head on Susan's shoulder, and they walk on, unaware of James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burst of laughter.  It is dinner.  Seated are Ann,  Matthew, Tom, Susan, James and JACEK, a professor from  Central Europe, mid-sixties, an old friend of Ann's.  Bet the housemaid, serves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy accent) The second is less pleasant.  A  Pole is confronted by a German and  a Russian soldier.  Which should  he shoot first?  The German first,  the Russian second.  Duty before  pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A more subdued response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard that one at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are a well-educated young  man. (to Ann) Tom has been reciting his English  kings and queens to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you socialist historians  in the West made kings and queens  out of date in schools?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell you that the history of  the monarchy is alive and well in  the national memory.  I shot a  commercial - a series of vignettes  of kings and queens В— Henry VIII,  Mary В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth I, and so on - and we  had a fantastic response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you advertising?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, some new lager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pleased to hear that there is  at least some national memory.  I  agree with Ann that the British  forget too quickly.  Here you have  enviable freedoms, and yet no  monuments to those who struggled  to win them for you.  Now that is  why I think there is hope for the  Poles, whoever occupies their  country.  They remember their dates,  and they keep adding to them.   December 1981, Gdansk 1980, 1976,  1970.  Katyn 1940, 1922 and so on.   It's a subversive list.  Say it  out loud on the streets of Warsaw  and you might get arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this last speech of Jacek's we SEE James trying to catch Susan's eye.  She glances up and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later. Wine glass in hand James goes upstairs.  He comes to Tom' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan has been seeing Tom into bed.  James watches from  the doorway.  She kisses her brother and turns out the  light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't close the door.  Don't turn  out the hall light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.  Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Susan linger in the semi-darkness outside Tom's room.  From downstairs comes the sound of boisterous  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen much of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's a bit of a madhouse.   For some reason a lot of my mother's  friends specialise in monologues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right, the professor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom comes out of his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Susy, it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom . .. bed!  Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom retreats into his bedroom.  James and Susan move to  the head of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, will you come on a walk with  me tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from below) Susan, James, are you up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann comes half-way up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's made some coffee.  Do you  want some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're in the library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann lingers a moment.  She wants James downstairs.  As  soon as she has gone, he kisses Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Strokes his face) Yes.  Might.  Remember, you're  here to talk to my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads the way downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library.  A fire burns.  Ann pours the coffee and is  highly aware of James when he comes in.  Jacek is a littl drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Susan, James.  Come and judge.   I am interrogating Matthew.  I am  asking him how a director of  advertisements and a socialist get  along so well together.  How does  the lion lie down with the lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By staying in town all week.  And  lying down with several lambs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so.  We meet half way.  Ann  has grown very fond of her material  comforts.  She even owns land with  keep out signs posted on the  boundaries.  And I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily, to James) I bought a wood because a local  farmer was going to cut it down.   The signs were already there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I earn so much money at what I do  that I can't even begin to defend  it.  I used to shoot a whole line  about the value and necessity of  advertising...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were more interesting then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but now I'm an agnostic.  So is  Ann, if she'd only admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, James.  Defend me from  this tripe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expectant pause.  Susan smirks.  James is out of his dept

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's no reason why a  socialist shouldn't like comfort,  or own a wood, or be very rich.   The problem is making all that  available to everybody ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All except Ann groan dismissively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, if everybody is to have  everything, then you need to plan  very carefully, you need to control  the future.  This is the tragedy  of Marxism.  The future is not  ours to control, nothing turns out  as we plan it. (to Ann) You remember that charming note of  Enzensberger's, Spanish anarchists  in 1898 looked forward to a glorious  future after the revolution В— a  world of incredibly tall shining  buildings, with elevators that  would save climbing stairs, electric  light for all, garbage disposal  chutes and wonderful household  gadgets.  This vision is now a  reality in our cities, the victory  has been won and it looks just  like defeat. ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan yawns conspicuously.  Everybody turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unrepentant) Sorry.  Tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning.  If possible, a beautiful day.   Betty is washing up a large pile of breakfast things.   From outside, the sound of much hilarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the back lawn Tom, Susan and Matthew are playing  football.  To one side, Jacek leans on his stick and  watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library.  Ann and James sit facing each other by the  fireplace.  The game of football can be heard.  From wher James sits he can see past and into the gardens, the  occasional glimpse of Susan, the enticing sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The references are to Hansard or  to newspapers.  I haven't got the  actual speeches now.  You'll have  to chase them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are transcripts of various  radio broadcasts, including  Gaitskill's, the one they tried to  stop.  You ought to have that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  Phone call for Mr  Penfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Hello... how did you get  this number?  I see.  Look, I'm  really sorry about last week, I...  no, I'm up here researching  something I... is she?.. . well,  don't they have painkillers for  that?... Oh, yeah... Look, tell  her 111 be there... I can't just  drop everything.  It'll probably  be the day after tomorrow...  Right... Ok... yes, goodbye. (to Ann) It's a relative of mine.  She's  not very well.  (He sits down again) I'm sorry.  What were you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of hours later.  Susan sits on a bench re-tying  the lace of her walking boot.  James stands, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy phoned this morning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's making plans for Brighton.   He thought we could travel down  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be fun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann appears from the house.  Tom follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Anyone for a walk?  Tom  isn't, I can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we were just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to walk, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I've been once today  already.  I'll stay here with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and I have been indoors all  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's very keen to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks with Tom towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding Tom's hand, she turns and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you when you get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James has been quickly outmanoeuvred by Susan.  He stands awkwardly for a moment, collecting himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dyke across the marshes, the sand dunes, the sea.   During Ann's monologue (broken up where appropriate) we  SEE the two sometimes IN CLOSE, sometimes as MINUTE FIGUR in this immense landscape. James follows Ann along the dyke.  They stop and she poin out a wooded hill, well inland.  Later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I began to listen to what the  well-off were saying about the  poor now В— the war had just ended,  and the language was much the same  as it had been before the first  Reform Act.  A small minority  thought that England was really  theirs, they had made it, they  owned it.  The rest, the wage  earners, were foreigners, outsiders  intent on wrecking it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't Evelyn Waugh say that the  country under Atlee seemed to be  under enemy occupation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he?  I left school and worked  for the Labour Party.  My older  brother, George, had just been  killed in Greece, and he'd been an  active member.  I hero-worshipped  him.  He was 25 years old ... (she trails off) It was an exciting time for us,  those first couple of years after  the war.  We thought the country  was about to become a true  democracy.  I can understand why  people of your generation want to  write about that time.  They feel  betrayed.  They want to know what  went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What went wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, many things.  Inertia ... Stalin  and the Cold War... a failure of  nerve.  We took the seediest, most  inefficient fifth of the economy  into State care, paid out millions  for it, put the same old duffers  in charge.  A new broom with very  old bristles.  When the Tories  were returned, I went and sat in  the BM and wrote my little book on  Chartism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.  Walking home

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like admitting it, but the  truth is, I am happy.  Matthew's  right.  I like comfort.  I like  doing my own work and not having  to teach.  I love my house and the  garden, and my wood. (she stops) And I'm very happy walking here  with you.  (She takes his hand.)  You have such a quiet, strong sense  of purpose.  Energy.  I think I'll  rely on you to take the  uncomfortable stands in life.   I've done my bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other.  Ann moves in to kiss James passionately.  He complies.  A jet fighter flies in low over the marshes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and Tom, who wears pyjamas and dressing-gown, are  playing Chess.  James watches Susan.  Tom is noisily,  bossily instructing her in the rules.  Matthew is  approaching James, about to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just might give you a ring when  we get back to London.  There's  one or two things I'd like to...  Will you let me have your number  before you leave?  Have you ever  watched a commercial being made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's worth seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment of awkwardness.  James squeezes past  Matthew and goes towards Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library.  A moment later.  James has just come in.   Ann hands him a silver framed photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to show you.  It was taken  six months before he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The resemblance between James and the dead brother should be clear.  James studies the photograph.  He looks up.   Ann is gazing at him steadily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later.  Ann, Matthew, Susan and James.  A  certain strain.  The sound of knives and forks only.  In  the hall the PHONE RINGS.  They hear Betty pick it up.   Still holding the receiver she pushes open the dining-roo door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Matthew) It's for you, Mr Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others go on eating, acutely aware of Matthew's  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the hall) Hello... Oh, hi... well, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the door shut with his foot.  James looks at  Susan.  Susan glances at her mother.  Ann knows it is one of Matthew's girlfriends.  She goes on eating, a brave bu failing attempt to appear untouched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very late, the same night.  From the point of view of an  intruder we move into the room.  James is asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) James... James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps awake.  We SEE what he sees.  Ann sits on the  edge of his bed, in tears.  She touches his face.  She  leans over and embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later.  The bedside lamp is on.  James lies stil his expression numb.  The bedclothes are in disarray.  Hi bedroom door is just closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Newsroom at its busiest, as in Scene One.  Linger on  the activity before finding James.  He sits writing a rep in longhand, referring to News Agency material.  Much  dictating going on around him, so that Philip who sits  across from him has almost to shout to be heard.  He has  picked up a phone and is covering the mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that lady from Norfolk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry.  He doesn't  seem to be here ... No ... Yes, if  I see him, I will. .. Goodbye.   She's going to phone back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time tell her I've gone away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha.  James giving some woman the  old heave-ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rim smile) Exactly that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT SHOT of Edward on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, you don't know me.  My name's  Edward Long.  I'm a friend of James  Penfield.  He asked me to phone  you.  I don't know what any of  this means, but he said you would  understand ... Yes, that's right.   He said he's got to go away for a  while, and that he'll be writing  to you and please don't try and  contact him ... Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling away, we see where we are.  James sits in a chair reading a magazine.  God, that was terrible.  Don't ever  ask me another favour like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were wonderful.  I'm very  grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hung up.  Why couldn't you  just write to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, sooner or later. (standing) Trouble is I hate writing letters.   Now, where are we going to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we SEE first is the actual set and only subsequently the surrounding technical apparatus of film-making.  We  are suddenly in a deeply contented pre-war middle-class  sitting-room.  Guide track: sweet, period music.  Dad sit in an armchair reading a newspaper.  A pipe is near at  hand.  To one side, a wireless.  At his feet, a girl play with a doll; a boy plays with a model steam engine. Mum enters with a tray of steaming hot drinks.  As she  sets down the tray on the arm of Dad's chair, the music  peaks and the children half rise and arrange themselves o either side of Dad's legs.  Everyone smiles up at Mum.   Once this has unfolded, we pull back to see the camera  crew, continuity, make-up etc. James is standing to one  side watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ... cut.  Steve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ((camera-man) Not the best, guv'nor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... we'll go again, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew to ad lib instructions to actors and crew.  He  notices James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, good, you made it.  We're  just going to do one more take,  then we'll break for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commercial is set up and shot again, with Matthew  continuing to give ad libbed directions.  As soon as the  take is over, Matthew snatches his jacket, gives a quick  kiss to a young woman who could well be his current lover and steers James out of the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, James.  Come on.  Let's go  before the clients get hold of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch time.  Matthew stands at the bar where he is buying drinks and lunch.  Then the two men sit at a small table  face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you another thing.  We  might have led the world once into  the Industrial Revolution, now we  lead with television commercials.   We're the best, it's as simple as  that.  Even the Americans will  admit it now ... the camera work,  the acting, the scripts, special  effects.  We've got the lot.  Nearly  all the good directors here have  ambitions to make serious films. (a sudden laugh) That food you're eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you call it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.  Ploughman's Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ploughman's Lunch.  Traditional  English fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact it's the invention of an  advertising campaign they ran in  the early sixties to encourage  people to eat in pubs.  A completely  successful fabrication of the past,  the Ploughman's Lunch was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look at James's plate, the unappetising food.  Matthew takes a long drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, James.  There's something  else I want to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty broadminded, and I'd  rather be frank than have everybody  misunderstanding one another.  If  you see what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James does not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan told me that your visits to  Norfolk had ... well, an ulterior  motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't really interested in  Suez at all.  Incredibly enough,  you were interested in my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, let me go on before you  get the wrong idea.  Ann and I  have kept to our separate bedrooms  for the last three years.
