And I  can't imagine that Susan hasn't  hinted at the kind of life I lead  in London.  I'm not telling you  how to run your affairs.  I'm just  saying ... I don't mind.  I'm giving  you permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE IN on James's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James drives towards Susan's flat.  Jeremy sprawls in the back seat, slowly peeling the foil from a champagne bottl Both are well-dressed.  As they draw up outside Susan's  flat, Jeremy leans forward and murmurs in James's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still in love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the horn and gets out.  Jeremy gets out too.   Susan comes down the steps.  She is also smartly dressed. She kisses James.  He takes her small suitcase and puts i in the boot.  She kisses Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling Susan.  You look like an  angel.  But where's your hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't let you in without one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James hands Susan into the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brighton, James!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car slips through the London traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the car, a few minutes later.  Much hilarity.  Susan i holding a glass ready as Jeremy eases out the cork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't point it at James!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voila!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cork flies.  The champagne is poured.  Susan hands a  glass to James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the ninety-ninth conference of  the National Union of Conservative  and Unionist Associations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All repeat the toast with various stumbling inaccuracies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James drives into a multi-storey car park.  Jeremy gets  out of the car and goes to look at the view which is of  modern office developments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hah - the seaside!  Isn't it  heavenly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan joins Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy is taking out his Press Pass and pinning it to his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd look naked without one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes!  Where's mine?  I want to  look like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James joins them.  There follows a little charade of mock sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy and Susan chorus a sympathetic moan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, Jeremy and Susan walk along the promenade and cros the road towards the Grand Hotel.  The Conference Centre  is visible and so too are the POLICE and DEMONSTRATORS.   Jeremy has linked arms with Susan.  James lags behind a  little.  Jeremy tells a joke, barely audible above the  SOUND of TRAFFIC and the CHANTS of the PROTESTORS.  Susan giggles as she and Jeremy skip forward to dodge the traff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby is crowded with DELEGATES, MPs, PRESS and TV  PEOPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes my deep throat.  Excuse  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy darts away.  Susan is looking about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we have a drink or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... excuse me.  There's Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELEGATES and MPs, and MEDIA PEOPLE, are taking tea on th long balcony of the Grand Hotel.  Jeremy is interviewing  an MP.  James and Susan sit at the same table listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the theory goes, you'll be  back in favour.  In line for a  real job.  Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a theory ... interesting.   Oh, excuse me, there's Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MP makes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see him too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy leaves.  James comes and sits closer to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't seem to get much time to  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An announcement comes through on the hotel's P.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Susan Barrington, Miss Susan  Barrington.  A phone call for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan makes a half-hearted apologetic gesture and leaves. As she goes she passes Jeremy who holds a Press Pass for  James.  He kneels by James's chair and pins the card to  his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Sir James Penfield ...  services during the Norfolk  campaign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three walk towards the Conference Centre, along the  gauntlet of PROTESTORS and ONLOOKERS.  Among them are Car and Betty, holding a placard which says 'Women's Peace  Camp'.  They catch sight of James.  Some puzzled  recognition.  James hurries away from the women and throu the doors into the Centre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, Susan and Jeremy come onto the Press balcony and  find their seats while FRANCIS PYM delivers a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was they who rebuffed aggression,  they who struck such a powerful  blow for democracy .. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan) I managed to book us a table at  Wheelers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe this will prove of wider  significance even than the event  itself.  We were seen to be fighting  to defend principles which are  fundamental to free nations  everywhere, and our reputation has  been enhanced as a result.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan) Francis is in cracking form, don't  you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, Jeremy and Susan.  Journalists, delegates etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphant, excited) It was incredible.  He came back,  made a pompous little bow and said,  'My dear girl you may film me all  afternoon if you wish.' And he's  promised not to talk to the Press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because he desires you.  The  women get all the breaks at these  conferences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true!  I was here last year  doing a piece, remember?  I was in  the bar with all these Northern  trade unionists and their sponsored  MPs.  They were all incredibly fat  and beery, huge trousers and braces.   And so sweet.  They all stood round  me like children saying 'You!   Working for television?  You're  just a young thing.'  They wouldn't  let me buy drinks even when I told  them the programme was paying.   They kept looking at my pass which  was pinned here and saying (Mock Yorkshire.) 'Oo, can I?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then one of them was sick all over  your new dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he wasn't.  He just lowered  himself into a bar stool and said... (Yorkshire) 'Oo I do feel bad.  I 'ad three  pints of lager and six onion  bajees!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go.  See you at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses them both.  They watch her go.  Their differen expressions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six onion bajees!  Great girl. (then, confidential) Did you shake the mother off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big mistake, I think.  You might  have learned a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden) Are you up to something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy shrugs innocently and shows his empty hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James wanders through the Centre in search of Susan.  He  enters the debating chamber.  MICHAEL HESELTINE is  addressing the Conference.  James wanders out to the spac below the platform where journalists and photographers ar gathered.  He goes up the aisles between the seated  delegates.  No sign of Susan.  He leaves the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....left-wing councils employ labour  candidates in the paid voluntary  sector.  We now face a professional  left financed at the ratepayer's  and tax payer's expense!  Just  more money is not a solution in  itself.  As we have given more  money to the professional left...

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY, CONFERENCE CENTRE. DAY
dialogues.text: Much later.  James crosses the crowded lobby, still in  search of Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James climbs the stairs to the Press balcony.  He hears  Mrs Thatcher's voice, and from the street below, the  chanting of protestors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not going to be a speech  about the Falklands campaign,  although I would be proud to make  one.  But I want to say just this  because it is true for all our  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James passes through the doors and finds a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spirit of the South Atlantic  was the spirit of Britain at her  best.  It has been said that we  surprised the world, that British  patriotism was rediscovered in  those spring days.  Mr President,  it was never really lost!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James suddenly notices Susan down on the lower floor.  Sh passes through the doors and is gone.  James gets to his  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it would be no bad thing if  the feeling that swept over the  country then were to continue to  inspire us.  But if there was any  doubt about the determination of  the British people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy and Susan come through the doors onto the Press  balcony.  James stops.  They have not seen him.  He watch as they stand together.  Clearly a new intimacy has been  established.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it was removed by men and women  who a few months ago brought a  renewed sense of pride and self- respect to our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy kisses the nape of Susan's neck.  They are not  interested in staying for the speech.  James watches ston as they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were for the most part young.   Let all of us here, and in the  wider audience outside, pause and  reflect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Numbed, James returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...on what we who stayed at home  owe to those who sailed and fought  and lived and died and won.  If  this is tomorrow's generation,  then Britain has little to fear in  the years to come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mix to the last sentence of the Prime Minister's speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will tell the people the truth,  and the people will be our judge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James sits through the standing ovation.  The delegates  cheer, Land of Hope and Glory' is sung.  James chews his  nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours later.  WORKMEN are dismantling the platforms, taki away props, taking down the Conference backdrop and sloga In LONG-SHOT we SEE Jeremy making his way between the row of chairs.  James pursues him enraged, shouting.  The ad  libbed obscenity can barely be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Jeremy. James's rage is spent.  It has collapsed into bitterness. The two men stop under a street lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan and I are very old friends,  James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were obviously getting  nowhere with her.  I was waiting  for the right moment to tell you  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.  You even cooked up that  Norfolk trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might have worked.  Really.  I  would have been delighted for you  if it had.  But she wasn't  interested.  Not my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a piece of shit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've known Susan for more than  fifteen years.  James, we're old  allies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this last word, James looks up.  Jeremy walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few weeks later.  We don't see James.  We SEE and HEAR  words pounding onto the PAGE.  A fury in the typing.  The page is pulled clear.  SILENCE.  We STAY ON the TYPEWRITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is leaving in a hurry.  He pulls on a thick overcoa gathers up some papers, ignores someone who calls after  him as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANGHAM PLACE
dialogues.text: James leaves Broadcasting House and walks towards Oxford  Circus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold stands by his desk as James comes in, pouring two  glasses of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James... I can't begin to tell you  how pleased we all are.  (he hands James a  glass) Congratulations, and I really mean  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's everything we wanted.  A very  good read.  A terrific piece of  work.  So, here's to you and Suez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE IN, the glasses touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of mourners round a grave.  A grey day.  A priest reads from the Book of Common Prayer, but his voice is  virtually lost to us.  We find James's father, hunched in his overcoat, face immobile with grief.  Next to him, Jam expressionless. James glances at his watch. FREEZE FRAME. OPTICAL ZOOM.
